quiz.title: Verbal to Inequality Translation
quiz.subtitle: Unit 6 Quiz 2: Writing Inequalities from Verbal Descriptions
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Translating Word Problems and Phrases into Mathematical Inequalities

questions.question: Translate: 'A number is at least 7'
questions.explanation: 'At least' means 'greater than or equal to.' So 'at least 7' means $x ≥ 7$.

questions.question: Translate: 'A number is less than or equal to -4'
questions.explanation: 'Less than or equal to' translates directly to $≤$. So $x ≤ -4$.

questions.question: Translate: 'The product of 3 and a number exceeds 15'
questions.explanation: 'Exceeds' means 'is greater than.' Product of 3 and x is 3x. So $3x > 15$.

questions.question: Translate: 'A number is no more than 12'
questions.explanation: 'No more than' means 'less than or equal to.' So $x ≤ 12$.

questions.question: Translate: 'Twice a number is at most 20'
questions.explanation: 'At most' means 'less than or equal to.' Twice a number is 2x. So $2x ≤ 20$.

questions.question: Translate: 'A number decreased by 5 is greater than 8'
questions.explanation: 'Decreased by 5' means subtract 5: $x - 5$. 'Greater than' is >. So $x - 5 > 8$.

questions.question: Translate: 'The quotient of a number and 4 is less than 9'
questions.explanation: 'Quotient' means division. 'A number and 4' means x divided by 4: $\frac{x}{4}$. 'Less than' is <. So $\frac{x}{4} < 9$.

questions.question: Translate: 'Three more than a number is at least 10'
questions.explanation: 'Three more than a number' means $x + 3$. 'At least' means ≥. So $x + 3 ≥ 10$.

questions.question: Translate: 'The sum of a number and 8 is no less than 15'
questions.explanation: 'Sum' means addition: $x + 8$. 'No less than' means 'not less than' or 'greater than or equal to.' So $x + 8 ≥ 15$.

questions.question: Translate: 'Half of a number is more than 6'
questions.explanation: 'Half of a number' means $\frac{x}{2}$. 'More than' means >. So $\frac{x}{2} > 6$.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You master translating verbal phrases into inequalities, including all key phrases like 'at least,' 'at most,' and 'exceeds.'
scoreMessages.70: Strong skills! Focus on distinguishing similar phrases: 'more than' vs 'at least,' 'less than' vs 'at most.'
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Practice: 1) Identifying key inequality words, 2) Translating word problems into algebraic expressions, 3) Choosing correct inequality symbol.
scoreMessages.0: Start with common phrases: 'at least' = ≥, 'at most' = ≤, 'more than' = >, 'less than' = <. Then build the algebraic expression.
